greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of distinct quarter-squares dividing n.
comment: For more information about the quarter-squares see A002620.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: For n = 12 the quarter-squares <= 12 are [0, 0, 1, 2, 4, 6, 9, 12]. There are five quarter-squares that divide 12; they are [1, 2, 4, 6, 12], so a(12) = 5.
mathematica: qsQ[n_] := AnyTrue[Range[Ceiling[2 Sqrt[n]]], n == Floor[#^2/4]&]; a[n_] := DivisorSum[n, Boole[qsQ[#]]&]; Array[a, 110] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 12 2018 *)
results.author: _Omar E. Pol_, Jun 19 2014
